meanings.definition: Obtain (something) by devious or cunning methods.
meanings.sent1: He tried to wangle a free ticket to the movie by pretending to be someone else.
meanings.sent2: She managed to wangle her way into the exclusive party by sweet-talking the bouncer.
meanings.sent3: The clever fox wangled some extra treats from the farmer by pretending to be hungry.
meanings.sent4: The sly cat wangled its way into the house through the open window.
meanings.sent5: The crafty magician wangled a rabbit out of the hat to surprise the audience.

meanings.definition: Manage to manipulate or control (a situation) to one's advantage.
meanings.sent1: He always tries to wangle the outcome of the game in his favor.
meanings.sent2: She wangled her schedule to have more time for her hobbies.
meanings.sent3: The student wangled a way to get an extension on the assignment by feigning illness.
meanings.sent4: The politician wangled the votes in his district to secure his position.
meanings.sent5: The clever negotiator wangled a better deal for her client by using her skills.

meanings.definition: To use devious or dishonest methods to achieve one's goals.
meanings.sent1: He wangled his way to the top by stepping on others.
meanings.sent2: She wangled her promotion by spreading false rumors about her colleagues.
meanings.sent3: The con artist wangled his victims out of their money through deceitful schemes.
meanings.sent4: The thief wangled his escape from the police by pretending to be injured.
meanings.sent5: The dishonest salesman wangled his customers into buying unnecessary products.
